items.title: The first 100% autonomous coast-to-coast drive on Tesla FSD V14.2! 2 days 20 hours, 2732 miles, zero...
items.content:
The first 100% autonomous coast-to-coast drive on Tesla FSD V14.2! 2 days 20 hours, 2732 miles, zero interventions.

This one is special because the coast-to-coast drive was a major goal for the autopilot team from the start. A lot of hours were spent in marathon clip review sessions late into the night looking over interventions as we attempted legs of the drive over time - triaging, categorizing, planning out all the projects to close the gap and bring the number of interventions to zero.

Amazing to see the system actually get there and huge congrats to the team!

items.summary: Karpathy announces first 100% autonomous coast-to-coast drive on Tesla FSD V14.2 - 2732 miles over 2 days 20 hours with zero interventions. Describes this as a major longtime goal of the Autopilot team.
items.reasoning: Historic autonomous driving milestone from highly credible source (former Tesla AI Director). Extremely high engagement (14k likes, 978k views). Represents major technical achievement in self-driving technology.

items.content:
As 2025 comes to a close üéÅ, I want to highlight the evolution of @llama_index as a company
üö´ We are no longer ‚Äúa RAG framework‚Äù
‚úÖ We‚Äôve built best-in-class technology around document OCR + workflows to provide high-quality context to *any* emerging agent application out there

Context and agent engineering are ever evolving (e.g. RAG 1.0 is dead, MCP might be dead too, nowadays it‚Äôs all about coding agents + skills + file search/coding execution).
But has remained constant is the need for highly-accurate/cost-effective modules to parse the most complex document types. No matter how good the models become, there is no way for them to read file binaries on their own. You need an accurate translation layer to make sense of the vast amounts of unstructured file containers.

Our mission is to automate knowledge work over your documents. And that starts by making sense of your document-based data.
We‚Äôve seen a massive spike in users, have processed half a billion pages, and have crossed 25M+ monthly downloads on our LlamaCloud client package.

Check out everything we‚Äôve released this year:
‚≠êÔ∏è LlamaParse v2: massive upgrades to our parsing quality
‚≠êÔ∏è LlamaSheets: Excel API
‚≠êÔ∏è LlamaClassify/LlamaSplit: complementary blocks to classify/postprocess your docs
‚≠êÔ∏è LlamaAgents: initial e2e templates to help your orchestrate your document workflows

Whether you‚Äôre an AI startup or F500 enterprise, if you need document processing tech, come follow us / check us out!

Here‚Äôs to a wonderful 2026 üìàüçæ

https://t.co/pIbRwaVBoP

items.title: Looking back on AI progress in 2025: people are increasingly weighing how AI should fit into our liv...
items.content:
Looking back on AI progress in 2025: people are increasingly weighing how AI should fit into our lives and how vital it is for the United States to lead in its development. Being pro-AI does not mean being anti-regulation. It means being thoughtful ‚Äî crafting policies that secure AI‚Äôs transformative benefits while mitigating risks and preserving flexibility as the technology continues to evolve rapidly.

This year, my wife Anna and I started getting involved politically, including through political contributions, reflecting support for policies that advance American innovation and constructive dialogue between government and the technology sector. These views are grounded in a belief that the United States must work closely with builders, researchers, and entrepreneurs to ensure AI is developed responsibly at home and that we remain globally competitive.

AI has the potential to democratize entrepreneurship and the American dream, make healthcare more affordable and effective, provide access to high-quality education, accelerate scientific discovery, expand economic opportunity, and strengthen national competitiveness and security. We feel this potential personally; through Anna‚Äôs experience navigating the healthcare system with complex chronic conditions that don‚Äôt fit neatly into any specialty, we‚Äôve seen firsthand how AI can empower people and lead to better health outcomes. AI represents an opportunity to truly improve healthcare, one we shouldn‚Äôt squander.

We‚Äôve been encouraged by the growing seriousness with which policymakers in Washington are approaching US leadership in AI, which we‚Äôve long believed depends on optimism, curiosity to explore, and serious infrastructure development. As I expressed at a recent White House technology leaders‚Äô dinner, it‚Äôs been great to see the president‚Äôs and his administration‚Äôs willingness to engage directly with the AI community and approach emerging technology with a growth-focused mindset and goal of helping to ensure continued US leadership in AI and supporting American economic competitiveness.

We believe that AI can be a force to improve quality of life for every human (and for every animal). Excited for the progress 2026 will bring!

items.title: As spotted by @eliebakouch & @natolambert, Korea's AI is on fire these days thanks to the public sup...
items.content:
As spotted by @eliebakouch & @natolambert, Korea's AI is on fire these days thanks to the public support for open-source AI with the "Sovereign AI Foundation Model‚Äù project!

Just in the past few days, three beautiful open models were announced:

- K-Exagone from @LGUS, a 236B fine-grained MoE design (23B active) that shines in Korean and multilingual, optimized with Multi-Token Prediction (MTP), enabling self-speculative decoding that boosts inference throughput by approximately 1.5x.

- Solar Open by @upstageai: 102B / 12B Mixture-of-Experts architecture models with 102B total / 12B active parameters trained entirely from scratch: https://t.co/scn6L7N0HH

- A.X K1 by @SKtelecom: a 519B total param, planned to release on 4th of January from SKT: https://t.co/PhBwE0QJLo

In 2026, all countries in the world should make it the number 1 priority to push for open-source AI as the most promising factor for competitiveness, job creation, economic growth and sovereignty!

Remember when AWS first came out?

The people who made a fortune deploying to AWS weren't the ones w...
items.content:
Remember when AWS first came out?

The people who made a fortune deploying to AWS weren't the ones who waited for Terraform or Kubernetes.

They were the ones SSH-ing into EC2 instances, manually configuring security groups, breaking things, and figuring out stuff as they went.

AI tooling is at the same stage right now.

Nothing is set. Everything is still evolving.

This is your chance to be one of the people who figure things out. This is the time to be one of those "early adopters" and stay ahead of the pack.

items.title: This year was so rich in cool stuff, so you never know what new cool research will be published tomo...
items.content:
This year was so rich in cool stuff, so you never know what new cool research will be published tomorrow.

This is the last day of the year, however, so I can safely publish the The Most Important AI Papers of 2025 curriculum: https://t.co/fGEEd93F2A

The curriculum now contains these papers:

- DeepSeek-R1 incentivizes reasoning in LLMs through reinforcement learning

Demonstrates how pure reinforcement learning can incentivize the emergence of sophisticated reasoning patterns in LLMs, potentially surpassing human-demonstration limits.

https://t.co/g6A2Xpgcu3

- Efficient Rectification of Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning Inconsistencies by Abductive Reflection
 
Presents a highly efficient method called Abductive Reflection (ABL-Refl) that significantly improves Neuro-Symbolic AI systems by proactively identifying and rectifying inconsistencies in neural network outputs using domain knowledge, leading to superior accuracy and reduced training resources.

https://t.co/vvfYF69bwv

- Gated Attention for Large Language Models: Non-linearity, Sparsity, and Attention-Sink-Free

Introduces a simple, head-specific sigmoid gate applied after Scaled Dot-Product Attention (SDPA) that consistently improves LLM performance, training stability, and mitigates the attention sink issue.

https://t.co/hVzGRN4Bv4

- Learning Dynamics of LLM Finetuning
 
Presents a novel framework that explains complex LLM finetuning behaviors, including hallucination and DPO's "squeezing effect," offering practical insights for improving alignment performance.

https://t.co/fQs45SptZm

- SAM 3: Segment Anything with Concepts

Doubles the accuracy of existing systems by introducing SAM 3, a unified model that detects, segments, and tracks objects in images and videos using concept prompts, significantly advancing promptable concept segmentation.

https://t.co/ST4TvvJeV2

- Safety Alignment Should Be Made More Than Just a Few Tokens Deep

Demonstrates how "shallow safety alignment" in LLMs creates critical vulnerabilities, and proposes methods to deepen this alignment for more robust AI safety.

https://t.co/aYYXiVlFwK

- Train for the Worst, Plan for the Best: Understanding Token Ordering in Masked Diffusions
 
Demonstrates how adaptively choosing token decoding order can dramatically boost the performance of Masked Diffusion Models, enabling them to solve complex tasks like Sudoku with superior accuracy to much larger autoregressive models.

https://t.co/m6vDn8qSzA

- Why Diffusion Models Don't Memorize: The Role of Implicit Dynamical Regularization in Training

Reveals how an implicit dynamical regularization in training prevents diffusion models from memorizing, maintaining generalization even in heavily overparameterized settings.

https://t.co/gyXAXq854u

- Does Reinforcement Learning Really Incentivize Reasoning Capacity in LLMs Beyond the Base Model?

Demonstrates that current Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) methods for LLMs primarily improve sampling efficiency of existing reasoning patterns rather than developing genuinely new reasoning capabilities, highlighting the need for improved RL paradigms to unlock true innovation.

https://t.co/vc94o7CVpu

Bookmark the curriculum, as about a dozen more papers will be added to it during the upcoming weeks and months: https://t.co/fGEEd93F2A

items.title: Ivy League to Carnegie Mellon - AI Degree Boom is Exploding‚Äîand Campuses Are Running Out of Space - ...
items.content:
Ivy League to Carnegie Mellon - AI Degree Boom is Exploding‚Äîand Campuses Are Running Out of Space - @CarnegieMellon @PennEngineers 

At the center of this surge is Chris Callison-Burch, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania an Ivy League, institution. When he first taught his A.I. course in 2018, enrollment hovered around 100. Seven years later, the class has exploded to ~500 in-person, ~250 remote learners, and another 100‚Äì200 on the waitlist. The course now occupies Penn‚Äôs largest lecture hall, with Callison-Burch noting that further growth would require moving classes into the university‚Äôs sports stadium.

This demand runs far beyond the Ivy League. Across the country, both elite and public institutions are experiencing similar surges:

Carnegie Mellon University, long regarded as a global leader in artificial intelligence, continues to see overwhelming demand for its AI programs, reinforcing its status as a bellwether in the field.
The University at Buffalo expanded its AI master‚Äôs enrollment from just five students in 2020 to 100 in the previous year.
At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, undergraduate AI enrollment surged from 37 students in 2022 to more than 300.
Miami Dade College reported a 75% increase in AI enrollment since 2022, while other programs remained largely flat‚Äîexcept for a slight decline in traditional computer science.

Callison-Burch says the decline in traditional computer science education is becoming a national pattern, while demand for AI education is exploding. Many educators believe that AI-driven education is reshaping entry-level computing roles, prompting students to pivot toward specialized AI training. Some numbers maybe slightly rounded off for the sake of article. 

Experts offer a range of guidance for students navigating this shift:

Demis Hassabis urges students to immerse themselves deeply in AI.
Geoffrey Hinton advocates pairing mathematics and science with AI.
Yann LeCun emphasizes the importance of learning how to learn, recommending foundational fields like math, physics, and engineering for their long-term value.

References 

Tremayne-Pengelly, A. (2025, December 30). A.I. degrees boom as students prepare for an uncertain job market. Observer. https://t.co/I15NoBFV5w

University of Pennsylvania Engineering  (2024, May 3). Meet Chris Callison-Burch, MSE-AI online program director. https://t.co/d4DZIUlPiF

items.content:
But the hardest part is not the technology, it is the people.

By 2030, nearly 8 million US roles will be reshaped by agentic AI.

Many roles face 38 to 42 percent task automation.

Meanwhile, high skill workers could gain up to 15 hours per week if they learn to collaborate with AI agents.

The biggest missing capability is AI governance.

Only 44 percent of organizations have it.

This is why ServiceNow University caught my attention, a personalized, AI powered learning platform built to close the skills gap and create an AI ready workforce at scale.

The average company now runs 367 siloed apps.

That means fragmented workflows, inconsistent data, and governance that breaks at scale.

No AI can thrive inside that kind of digital fragmentation.

So ServiceNow is pushing a different model:

‚Üí One platform
‚Üí One data layer
‚Üí One multimodal AI interface (voice, text, images, automation)

A single system that carries context end to end and actually acts, not just advises.

items.title: First, Happy New Year everyone! It's been a wild ride. I can't wait for 2026, LFG! I love you all! ‚ù§...
items.content:
First, Happy New Year everyone! It's been a wild ride. I can't wait for 2026, LFG! I love you all! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Second, here's my conversation with Joel David Hamkins (@JDHamkins), mathematician and philosopher specializing in set theory, the foundations of mathematics, and the nature of infinity. We talk about paradoxes that challenged some of the greatest mathematicians of the 20th century, G√∂del Incompleteness theorems, the mathematical multiverse, the nature of truth, computation, and much more.

By the way, Joel is the #1 highest-rated user on MathOverflow, and writes a great blog called "Infinitely More".

It's here on X in full and is up everywhere else (see comment).

Timestamps:
0:00 - Introduction
2:17 - Infinity & paradoxes
49:27 - Russell's paradox
1:02:35 - G√∂del's incompleteness theorems
1:20:06 - Truth vs proof
1:31:30 - The Halting Problem
1:47:23 - Does infinity exist?
2:04:57 - MathOverflow
2:08:49 - The Continuum Hypothesis
2:18:36 - Hardest problems in mathematics
2:28:03 - Mathematical multiverse
2:46:55 - Surreal numbers
2:57:33 - Conway's Game of Life
2:59:49 - Computability theory
3:09:41 - P vs NP
3:12:58 - Greatest mathematicians in history
3:26:43 - Infinite chess
3:45:01 - Most beautiful idea in mathematics

items.title:
No one. No one will ever read anything that has even a slim chance of being slop.

The only exceptio...
items.content:
No one. No one will ever read anything that has even a slim chance of being slop.

The only exception is when you ask a question to a chatbot because you ask for slop on purpose. You want to save time and you are ready to tolerate slop for this.

It's unimaginable that someone thinks something like, "Let me sit and spend the next half-hour reading this slop."

It's unimaginable that someone refers something openly slop in an essay or an article.

By mistake? Possibly. On purpose: impossible.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov argues no one will read content that might be AI-generated 'slop', except when intentionally querying chatbots to save time.
items.reasoning: Interesting perspective on AI content consumption and authenticity concerns. Contributes to content authenticity discourse.

items.title:
Meet La Brea Tar Pits Museum Giant Lion at LA! 

Scientists Found the Remarkably Preserved Corpse of...
items.content:
Meet La Brea Tar Pits Museum Giant Lion at LA! 

Scientists Found the Remarkably Preserved Corpse of a 35,000-Year-Old Giant in Siberia Ice Age

The Giant lion at the La Brea Tar Pits Museum is a striking reconstruction of Smilodon fatalis, an extinct saber toothed cat whose lion-like build, powerful forelimb, and forward-facing gaze make the comparison to modern lions almost instinctive from earlier age. Smilodon filled a similar apex-predator role in Ice Age Los Angeles City, ambushing large herbivores such as ground sloths and bison near asphalt seeps that ultimately trapped predator and prey alike. Genomic research on a related but distinct saber-toothed lineagethe scimitar toothed cat Homotherium latidens reveals how deeply divergent these Ice Age cats were from modern felines, evolving unique adaptations for vision, metabolism, and hunting strategies over millions of years. Together, fossil evidence from La Brea and genomic insights from Homotherium underscore that this 'giant lion' represents not a modern cat ancestor, but a powerful, specialized predator from a lost evolutionary world. 

References

items.title: @NightSkyNow I propose that the comet core is tumbling (‚Äúrotating‚Äù), presenting different sides (alm...
items.content: @NightSkyNow I propose that the comet core is tumbling (‚Äúrotating‚Äù), presenting different sides (almost certainly chaotically) towards the Sun all along its journey through the Solar System. It is highly unlikely that either it formed with zero net spin (angular momentum L) or it currently has zero L after all of the outgassing and comet jet ejections. Newton‚Äôs 3rd law (of Action-Reaction) governs a lot of the ‚Äúodd‚Äù behaviors observed in comets. They are not point masses, but asymmetric conglomerates of ice, snow, rocks, gravel, boulders, pebbles, etc. with different compositions, volatility, cohesion, chemical reactivity to sunlight, and so forth. They are marvelous diverse objects birthed and shaped through billions of years of travel across a maelstrom of Milky Way environments. We are witnessing in real time the unraveling of some of that history.
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Detailed scientific explanation of comet behavior and physics
items.reasoning: Off-topic but demonstrates Kirk Borne's scientific expertise

items.content:
Most democracies fight corruption. Only the U.S. gave it the name of lobbying and legalized it.

I'm not even an American, but this bothers me for some reason. And I'm shocked that this doesn't bother most Americans.

Other than lobbying, I'm shocked by billion-dollar presidential election campaigns. Isn't it clear even to a complete retard that these billions, with interest, are expected to be repaid by the future president to those who "donated" this money?
